> We've a couple of places where we have threads waiting for eachother using
> java's wait() and notify() design. In general it worked fine. However
> every
> now and then (depending on user actions and what else the machine has
> running) we'd run into the problems "Missed notification" and "Early
> notification" which are described in thread books such as Paul Hyde's
> "Java
> Thread Programming". Solutions to these "standard" problems are also given
> in the thread books so we have now solved the problem.
> 
> What we do not have is a test that tells us that we've solved the problem!
> We only have tests that generally pass even when the problem is there!
> 
> We would like to write a test that specifically tests our wait()-notify()
> constructs for robustness against "Missed notification" and "Early
> notification". Has anybody already though through how best to test this?
> Or
> does anyone have a reference to an article or web where this test may be
> described in a generic way or with an example?

In my book: "Unit Testing in Java - How Tests Drive the Code"
(http://www.amazon.com/exec/obidos/ASIN/1558608680) I tackle the very problem you describe
in chapter 11. I show a way to detect the problem in certain situations. 

However, the inherent indeterminism requires a lot of effort to come up with
such a test suite. In most situations it's probably more effective to  have
the multi-threaded code reviewed by expeprienced "thread programmers". Even
better: Use threading libraries (eg the one described in Doug Lea's seminal
work "Concurrent Programming in Java")  which hide most of the intricacies of
threaded programming.

Johannes
